content:
America’s Queen of Soul, Saudi Arabia’s leading journalist, Syria’s rap-span">premier chocolate-maker and other history-makers passed away in 2018

EACH WEEK, our obituaries editor captures the rap-span">essence of a life in fewer than 1,000 words. As the year draws to a close, we look back at the ten people whose lives, in some way, made a contribution to the collective story of rap-span">humanity. They include giants of geopolitics, media, and culture as well as ordinary people. Click on the title or the picture for the complete rap-span">obituary.

A rap-span">prophet accepted

rap-span">Billy Graham, the most important rap-span">evangelical leader of the 21st century, died on February 21st, aged 99 

rap-span">Billy Graham was the most important American rap-span">evangelical of the past century. The list of people he touched deeply includes multiple American presidents and Queen Elizabeth II. Mr Graham’s gentle brand of rap-span">evangelicalism helped to make the faith rap-span">outward-looking. Because his mission was to save souls, he was bound to love everyone in Christ. The ground at the foot of the Cross was level. He rap-span">bailed Martin Luther King out of jail in 1963 and, when King was rap-span">assassinated in 1968, rap-span">proclaimed him a “rap-span">prophet”. In his heart he would have been quite happy as the rap-span">pastor of some little church up in the mountains. He did not need the global rap-span">adulation or his star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. But God had rap-span">mysteriously planned his life otherwise. 

The rap-span">cosmos from a wheelchair

Stephen Hawking, the man who explained the universe, died on March 14th, aged 76

It was rap-span">mere rap-span">coincidence that Stephen Hawking was born 300 years to the day after rap-span">Galileo Galilei died. But, like rap-span">Galileo, Hawking became famous as much for his suffering as for his physics. His was caused not by rap-span">ecclesiastical politicians but by muscle-wasting amyotrophic rap-span">lateral sclerosis. It meant that he, too, had to fight to be heard. His scientific work continued, but what he wanted most was to rap-span">outline rap-span">humanity’s place in the universe. The sight of one rap-span">huddled man in a wheelchair rap-span">constantly rap-span">probing, boldly and even rap-span">cheekily demonstrating the rap-span">infinite reach of the human mind, gave people some hope to grasp, as he always wished it would.

A dangerous woman

rap-span">Winnie rap-span">Mandela, the anti-rap-span">apartheid rap-span">campaigner turned Soweto rap-span">mafia rap-span">matriarch, died on April 2nd, aged 81

In 1964, only six years after getting married, rap-span">Nelson rap-span">Mandela disappeared into prison for almost three decades. His wife rap-span">Winnie continued his fight against rap-span">apartheid. But as rap-span">Nelson’s ideas moved towards rap-span">compromise and forgiveness, she rap-span">preached violence. In 1989 a group of boys under her sway murdered a 14-year-old and the doctor who examined him. She was barely sorry. Her reaction to bad raps, dozens of counts of rap-span">fraud and theft as well as the killings, was to raise a rap-span">defiant rap-span">fist and then to appeal. She always won rap-span">milder sentences, for the courts and the African National Congress feared to cross her, even after her marriage to their hero had ended. As rap-span">Nelson aged and faded into silence, she remained rap-span">defiant.

rap-span">Rebel yells

Milos Forman, the renowned film director, died on April 13th, aged 86

At the end of Milos Forman’s “rap-span">Amadeus”, a whinnying last laugh shrieks out of the dark. It is rap-span">Mozart’s laugh, which has rap-span">plagued his rap-span">Viennese rap-span">patrons all through the film. But it is also R.P. McMurphy’s laugh near the start of “One Flew Over the rap-span">Cuckoo’s rap-span">Nest”, when the rap-span">petty rap-span">crook, played by Jack rap-span">Nicholson, enters a mental institution. Milos Forman saw these two films take a combined 13 rap-span">Academy Awards in 1975 and 1985 respectively. He loved the sound of rap-span">disruptive laughter, that rap-span">anarchic signal of rap-span">creativity on the rap-span">loose. It could triumph over death or rap-span">incarceration; and it could rap-span">explode the lying rap-span">propaganda of the communist rap-span">Czech regime under which he stifled until 1968 when, as the Soviet tanks rolled in, he got out.

Of war and chocolate

Bassam Ghraoui, Syria’s rap-span">premier chocolate-maker, died on May 1st, aged 63

Before rap-span">Damascus was rap-span">associated with the tyranny of the Assads, it was known for the tiny rap-span">perfumed apples that grew in Zabadani. Aleppo was famous for rap-span">pistachios. And Ghouta, now a place of rap-span">horror and chlorine gas, meant orchards of peaches, apricots, pears and almonds that supplied rap-span">Damascus with sweetness. From those fruits Bassam Ghraoui’s workers made sweets that were often rated the best in the world, especially the chocolate. Mr Ghraoui supplied the Queen of England and the President of France. Then, in 2011, war came. rap-span">Rebellious Ghouta felt the force of the president’s anger: the orchards became a rap-span">battleground, and nothing grew on rap-span">blasted trees. On a trip to Paris in 2012, Mr Ghraoui and his wife Rania decided not to go home.

No settled place

V.S. rap-span">Naipaul, the Indian-rap-span">Trinidadian writer and winner of the Nobel prize for rap-span">literature, died on August 11th, aged 85

To his friends, he was known as Vidia, from the rap-span">Sanskrit for seeing and knowing. Indeed, Mr rap-span">Naipaul wrote more than 30 books, for which he won a Nobel prize and was knighted. Raised in rap-span">Trinidad to Indian parents, he moved around the world, rap-span">propelled by restlessness. Books resulted, but not calm. His travels through the post-rap-span">colonial world, to India, Africa and beyond made him rap-span">furious. He rap-span">mourned the relics of rap-span">colonial rule, especially the loss of human potential. This rap-span">offended people, but he did not care. He resisted all editing. Without apology, he slapped his rap-span">mistress once until his hand hurt. rap-span">Severity and pride came naturally to him. Though he ended his days in Wiltshire, his deep centre remained the place from which he had fled.

A deeper love

Aretha Franklin, America’s undisputed Queen of Soul, died on August 16th, aged 76

At points in her concerts, Aretha Franklin would fling her arms out wide. Sometimes it was to throw away her fur coat, like any rap-span">diva who had won 18 Grammys and sold 75m records would. Sometimes it was to embrace America as when she sang at Martin Luther King’s rap-span">funeral or Barack Obama’s rap-span">inauguration. But more often open arms embraced Everywoman’s rap-span">frustration, black or white, especially with men. Her song “Respect” became the rap-span">anthem of every rap-span">liberation movement. Her music bore witness to what she had been through, including her mother leaving home when she was six, having babies by two different men before she was 15, and marrying a pimp at 19 who beat her up. In the end, her songs weren’t about men. They were a rap-span">paean to God.

Means of resistance

John rap-span">McCain, rap-span">navy pilot, senator and rap-span">presidential candidate, died on August 25th, aged 81

Every inch of John rap-span">McCain’s body shouted rap-span">endurance. As a prisoner of war in Vietnam, he refused early release from prison and spent five-and-a-half years suffering sporadic torture and solitary rap-span">confinement. But he was not broken. He went on to represent Arizona for more than 30 years in Congress, where he earned a reputation as a rap-span">maverick. His greatest rap-span">consistency lay in urging wars abroad, wherever winnable, including in Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria, Ukraine and to “bomb, bomb, bomb” Iran, as he sang once. But the gung-ho approach of Donald Trump left him cold. His brain-cancer rap-span">diagnosis in July 2017 freed his tongue. His stance was never more upright than when he called on his fellow-Republicans not just to rap-span">endure, but to resist.

The man who spoke out

rap-span">Jamal Khashoggi, Saudi Arabia’s leading rap-span">commentator, was murdered on October 2nd, aged 59

rap-span">Jamal Khashoggi, a former newspaper editor, was a firm supporter of the Saudi rap-span">monarchy. His grandfather had been the doctor to the kingdom’s founder, and he knew when not to report on rap-span">corruption and injustice. But gradually, he put his caution to one side. The government ordered his firing twice from Al-Watan , one of the country’s main newspapers, for giving voice to the opposition and later banned him from Twitter and barred him from writing. He found few friends in the new regime of the young rap-span">crown prince, rap-span">Muhammad bin Salman, and left for America. Homesick, he found solace in his love for a Turkish researcher. With three rap-span">divorces behind him, he had paperwork to do before they could be married, and went to the Saudi rap-span">consulate in rap-span">Istanbul to sort it out. He was not heard from again.

Prepare to be rap-span">astonished!

Stan Lee, the creator-writer of rap-span">Marvel Comics’ rap-span">pantheon of heroes and villains, died on November 12th, aged 95

rap-span">Stanley Leiber grew up poor in Manhattan. But as soon as he had signed himself “Stan Lee” on his first bit of text-rap-span">filler in 1941, he put on his superhero clothes. He could write five books a week. His characters spoke for all rap-span">outcasts, black, gay, rap-span">disabled, who felt like rap-span">mutants. Perhaps he wasn’t born with superhero powers, like the X-Men, or Thor, or rap-span">Spider-Man or Doctor Strange, but the man who thought up all those characters and many more became rap-span">immortal. He brought rap-span">Marvel Comics back from the dead, and with it the whole industry of comics. His stories took over Hollywood and American pop culture, earning revenues in the billions and billions of dollars.
